Authors:
Fernanado E. Novas, Diego Pol, Juan I. Canale, Juan D.
Porfiri, Jorge O. Calvo
Title:
A bizarre Cretaceous theropod dinosaur from Patagonia and the
evolution of Gondwanan dromaeosaurids.
Journal:
Proceedings of the Royal Society of London, Biological
Sciences
Keywords:
Theropoda; Dromaeosauridae; Unenlagiinae; Cretaceous;
South America; forelimb
Abstract:
Fossils of a predatory dinosaur provide novel information
about the evolution of unenlagiines, a poorly known group of
dromaeosaurid theropods from Gondwana. The new dinosaur is the largest
dromaeosaurid yet discovered in the Southern Hemisphere and depicts
bizarre cranial and postcranial features. Its long and low snout bears
numerous, small-sized conical teeth, a condition resembling spinosaurid
theropods. Its short forearms depart from the characteristically
long-armed condition of all dromaeosaurids and their close avian
relatives. The new discovery amplifies the range of morphological
disparity among unenlagiines, demonstrating that by the end of the
Cretaceous this clade included large, short-armed forms alongside
crow-sized, long-armed, possibly flying representatives. The new
dinosaur is the youngest record of dromaeosaurids from Gondwana and
represents a previously unrecognized lineage of large predators in Late
Cretaceous dinosaur faunas mainly dominated by abelisaurid
theropods.
